ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: You learn how to speak, write, read, and comprehend the chinese language.
How to better listen, read, and speak Chinese

This course taught me fundamental Chinese grammar structures and expanded the vocabulary that I learned in CHNS110. The listening and speaking exercises also gave me more fluency in oral communication.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the strength is the small class format, allows for more interaction between the students and the teacher. I think the only weakness to this course, is it covers subjects a bit too fast. The book is 10 chapters, and I honestly think that as a student, I would learn more, and have a higher quality understanding if we went a bit slower in class, and only covered 7 or 8 chapters.
Great job engaging students with methods used and the textbook was interesting with the dialogue

The only criticism I have is that the professors do not cover any new vocabulary outside of the textbook or cultural aspects that are relevant today. I know that they have a strict curriculum that is already difficult to fit into one semester, but I think they could easily incorporate more common colloquial phrases into each chapter or show us more examples of Chinese food, transportation, shopping malls, etc during those units. Not to be tested on, but just to give us a better understanding of how we can practically use the language if we were to visit.

The course is very well structured. Every homework assignment has a combination of reading, listening, and writing exercises, which help develop the three main skill areas in foreign language. Although the course proceeds at a fast pace, the material is explained clearly and efficiently, so that you never feel lost. Also, the small class size fosters a tight-knit learning environment.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I found the teaching style very effective, even over zoom. The worst part about online class was that I had no incentive to practice my writing. Since the tests and homework mostly required us to type the characters, it was easy to get away with not having to practice writing every day. I also wish there was more opportunity to get to know our classmates, perhaps by giving us more time in breakout rooms.

All students were required to have their camera on during the lessons. This contributed to a tighter sense of community in the class, in spite of our being on Zoom. Sometimes, we would be assigned to breakout rooms to practice speaking with other students in our class. The breakout rooms, too, helped me get to know people in the class. However, the rooms were sometimes kept open for more time than we needed to complete the assigned activities. As a result, we would sometimes hang around without anything specific to do in the breakout room, which might not be the best use of class time.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you want to learn Chinese, then yeah. If you're looking for an easy language, Chinese is not easy at all.

Yes! It is a lot of work, and the material is significantly more difficult than CHNS 110, but I learned so much this semester. I found the one-on-one sessions with the professor every Wednesday very helpful and the weekly tutorial sessions were great for practicing my reading and speaking skills.

Yes. This course is a rigorous introduction to Chinese language and culture. It is not easy, but you make significant progress in a short amount of time. The reward is certainly worth the effort you put in.
yes! if you want to learn chinese

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Individual sessions every week with the teacher for 1 on 1 practice
